title: Tuesday, 16th October 2018
bodyHTML:
Blank canvas good morning everyone
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Dunno about Equiniti, sorry.

Soundbuy Morning
Equiniti Group PLC (EQN:LSE): Last: 213.30, up 11.3 (+5.59%), High: 213.30, Low: 201.00, Volume: 535.01k
Blank canvas BE is straight out of the traps this morning
BE11:06am

Should I put that in bold to stop a dozen arbs coming on to ask over the next hour or so? Dunno about Equiniti, sorry.

Manxish Morning all
11:07 am
BE11:07am

So anyway, this is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's whatever.

VV75 morning
tadam Anything on Assurant, also Betaville? Thanks.
BE11:08am

We've got the usual things to head through, such as Kantar and Merlin and so on.

Amatuerinvestor @BE , anything on Acadia Healthcare / Fevertree - both were mentioned on Betaville yesterday
BE11:09am

And no raw. None. Zero.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

If you want to read what Betaville's writing I suggest you pay for it.

undefined
VV75 I just read you are moving office probably
VV75 WPP buying your office
BE11:11am

Oh, here's a thing.

Soundbuy Do tell.............
11:11 am
BE11:11am

Property Week is reporting that the new owners of One Southwark Bridge -- as in, the FT offices -- might be WPP!

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Good moaning.
WPP PLC (WPP:LSE): Last: 1,052, up 4 (+0.38%), High: 1,059, Low: 1,047, Volume: 720.47k
BE11:12am

"Advanced talks," they're reporting.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Building's been for sale for a while: https://www.ft.com...-ba8f-ee390057b8c9

Ethelred Babcock and Boatman? Or was that covered yesterday?
BE11:13am

We, of course, are moving across the river to Bracken House. Anyway, enough shop. Let's head into what's moving.

undefined
11:13 am
BE11:14am

Wages up, sterling up, FTSE down.

wayneJ How many sqft is the FT building - just to get a reference for price per sq/ft - as £90M looks cheap at face value for that?
BE11:15am

0.4% at pixel. JMAT's leading the fallers.

Johnson Matthey PLC (JMAT:LSE): Last: 2,926, down 169 (-5.46%), High: 3,017, Low: 2,891, Volume: 516.04k
11:15 am
BE11:16am

Which is on the Volvo announcement that its emission control thingmy's rotting quicker than expected.

BE11:16am

Meaning its engines have been exceeding NOx emission limits

BE11:17am

There are a number of questions needing answered though. First, is JMat the supplier here?

11:17 am
BE11:17am

As per Citi ....

BE11:17am

JMAT does not disclose the names of its customers. The presumption is that with an estimated 60% global market share in HDD, JMAT has exposure to this issue. This may not be the case.

Shinshin UK unemployment down another 50k
BE11:18am

Secondly, how many Volvos are toxic?

Flaneur Wages up, house prices falling.... whodathunk a little X in a box could have brought so much joy?
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Back to the old NOx issues. Let us worry about a few city dwellers today but in doing so kill the planet and everyone on it. Carbon emissions increasing because of knee jerk idiots.
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Noting JMAT’s c.60% share, this would appear to be a specific issue and not a generic issue. Cummins has had a voluntary recall on 500k trucks on 2010-15 models, noting that the problem was “purely mechanical” , according to CARB, and not a safety risk and did not affect current model engine families. Volvo has not identified the scale of the issue at this time.

BE11:18am

And thirdly, what's the liability here?

BE11:18am

The fact that Volvo notes the impact is not consistent across vehicles and engines might suggest an issue at the engine and hence misuse of the catalyst precipitating in the degradation rather than purely component failure. In other words, it is likely that an investigation will be required to decipher the root cause.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian No offence to city dwellers BTW.
11:19 am
BE11:19am

So, is this an overreaction? Yeah, maybe, says Citi.

BE11:20am

In November 2017, JMAT settled with no admission of fault in relation to a claim following being made a defendant in contract dispute lawsuit alongside a supplier to an automotive OEM in the US. We judge this provides limited insight into the current situation given that this focused on light duty trucks, not heavy duty. In short, there are many moving parts, around which little is understood at this point. We see this as a short-term negative for sentiment but should not detract from significant earnings growth (12.8% CAGR FY18-21E) we expect from JMAT driven by the emissions abatement step-up for HDD, especially in Emerging Markets with China IV-a taking effect from July 1st, 2019 and Bharat VI after April 1, 2020 as well as in LDV in Europe with Euro 6d in 2020, where early adoption is likely, and the increasing market shares JMAT has announced in both diesel and gasoline.

Roidster morning all ;)
tadam Yes, well, not paying for Betaville. Equiniti, you covered. And there was something on Acadia yesterday. Whatever it is, this does not give you confidence: http://www.acadiaexposed.com/ So one would say there is a skew towards companies with issues.
Roidster @BE any news or opinions on RPC group?
BE11:21am

And backing into the story from the Volvo perspective ....

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Volvo says it is not yet possible to calculate the number of trucks affected, nor the potential cost of the possible recall, but that the costs "could be material". Given that Volvo delivers approx 150k trucks in the US and Europe combined a year, the installed base of trucks will be significant – in our view likely over 500k vehicles. What proportion is affected is more difficult to gauge, but should be significantly lower than that installed base number.

mbt SAFESTORE any news?
BE11:22am

Volvo reiterates that all of its products meet emissions standards at the time of initial delivery. Volvo has reported its own findings to the authorities, and is discussing remediation plans. Unlike the passenger car companies, Truck emissions seem to comply with emissions legislation under all current tests, and hence we view this as a quality recall issue rather than any issue with compliance and / or regulatory authorities. On that basis, we believe the eventual remediation cost will be contained and comfortably covered by current financial liquidity.

BE11:23am

That's Morgan Stanley.

11:23 am
undefined
BE11:23am

@MBT, Safestore's a Stifel upgrade.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Good stuff on JMAT BE. Very much appreciated.
BE11:24am

Up to buy in a note saying retail bad, industrial estates good.

11:24 am
Safestore Holdings PLC (SAFE:LSE): Last: 524.00, up 24.6 (+4.93%), High: 524.00, Low: 493.00, Volume: 136.13k
BE11:25am

Which is self explanatory really. The most interesting stuff in there is on Intu.

Intu Properties PLC (INTU:LSE): Last: 182.60, down 0.75 (-0.41%), High: 182.60, Low: 179.00, Volume: 515.19k
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Brookfield has deep pockets, and ordinarily we would question its appetite to take on such a problematic portfolio. However, the Peel Group forms part of the consortium, it owns almost a third of Intu, and its Chairman John Whittaker is Deputy Chairman of Intu. We think the consortium is likely to already have a warts-and-all view of Intu, either that or Peel Group is about to pull off an enormous coup using Brookfield’s capital to take Intu out of the glare of listed markets. If the take-out price is 228p, Intu’s current share price of 185p appears to suggest the probability of a bid is around 50%,

BE11:26am

A 50/50 probability of a bid looks a little generous to me, but what do I know?

BE11:26am

As said previously, we're a no raw session today.

DogDay Any idea why Pets at Home is being so massively shorted?
11:26 am
BE11:26am

We think that in the absence of a bid, Intu’s shares will drop to at least the 58% discount to NAV that they were at immediately prior to Brookfield’s announcement. We are forecasting Intu’s NAV to continue to fall, and the LTV rise over 50%, such that they would continue to de-rate. One year forward we forecast the NAV to reach 324p, and with the share price at a 60% discount to this, the implied share price is 130p, giving downside of 30%.

BE11:27am

And on Safestore, since it was mentioned.

BE11:27am

With the sector busy looking at the Shurgard IPO, we think Safestore may have been overlooked. The company has strong earnings growth potential, and offers exposure to both the UK and Paris self-storage markets.
With an unchanged target price of 585p, the shares offer a 17% total shareholder return over the next 12 months.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

They're sellers of Land Secs and downgrade British Land to hold. Buyers of Shaftesbury, LondonMetric, Workspace.

undefined
BE11:29am

@DogDay: the answer there's the vets JV.

wayneJ One point re Volvo is that these will be trucks used commercially. So presumably there might need to be compensation for owners for taking the vehicles out for a day or two
11:29 am
BE11:29am

Which we've talked about a few times here and a few times elsewhere, such as here: https://www.ft.com...-b7e0-52972418fec4

Pets at Home Group PLC (PETS:LSE): Last: 123.30, up 0.3 (+0.24%), High: 124.70, Low: 121.90, Volume: 826.36k
Tom Dalgleish @Dog, FWIW, here in Oz a vet care + vet retail roller-upper is also in the doghouse but nobody can find the pea in the thimble
DogDay Thanks
undefined
Excel Developer has Theresa May's world fallen apart yet?
Gillibrand Good Morning!
11:32 am
BE11:32am

On RPC ..... nope, no views.

RPC Group PLC (RPC:LSE): Last: 761.00, up 5 (+0.66%), High: 763.40, Low: 755.00, Volume: 318.67k
Excel Developer on Cabinet watch here...
GBKrona @BE - UBS note today cutting target prices on most insurers - any insights please?
BE11:34am

We've three weeks until the next PUSU and there's a bit of speculation around that the public interest from two PE bidders might flush out another.

Maverick RPC deadline 5th, by any chance Bryce have you seen any Tier 1 commentary on this please?
11:34 am
BE11:35am

Against that, you have the well documented concerns about RPC's rollup structure unfurling.

BE11:36am

As it stands we can add very little new. Sorry.

undefined
Maverick No worries, many thanks
Pharma @Tom "pea in the thimble"??
Tom Dalgleish as in trick
11:36 am
BE11:37am

UBS on insurance. Sure. That'll fill some time.

Tom Dalgleish apologies to millenials
Pharma @Tom, ah, thanks.
BE11:37am

It's negative on UK life because of bloody Brexit.

Patience @Tom - the shell game?
Flaneur Mr Lionels' Letter of the day tweet is quite good. As is the letter of the day.
BE11:37am

The Brexit timetable is closing in with key dates approaching The UBS house view is that a deal will be reached, but even in this instance UK parliamentary support remains uncertain and risks remain. In this report, we assess the potential implications to UK insurers. We highlight balance sheet and operational exposures across life and P&C, with valuations implying the risk of an adverse scenario is not fully priced in. Our interactive model illustrates sensitivities to key risks, namely credit ratings, property exposures and claims inflation which are under-appreciated, in our view. We turn more negative on the UK Life sub-sector owing to balance sheet risks, downgrading from our second most preferred to fifth.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

Life insurers are balance sheet businesses with leveraged business models. We illustrate that an adverse Brexit scenario resulting in a UK credit cycle would impact on Solvency II ratios via higher capital requirements. This would lower solvency by ~6-38ppts, in some cases leading to ratios falling below the self-imposed floor levels indicated by management (L&G). Further, the impact at entity level is proportionately higher and could leave buffers thin, impacting cash remittances if impacts proved prolonged. More illiquid markets, where insurers have been increasing allocations (0.4-1.9x TNAV), could see large negative valuation swings. The implication of this for dividends in an adverse Brexit scenario is under-appreciated and not priced in, in our view

BE11:38am

For UK P&C insurers, we find few jurisdictional issues from Brexit, with companies able to write EU business via EU subs; costs and capital fungibility would see marginal impacts only. The main dynamic, in our opinion, would be any potential impact on claims inflation via GBP weakness (imported parts inflation), potential tariffs or labour shortages. For UK motor, companies have a good track record of passing on higher claims costs and, given the sub-sector trades with pricing, higher claims inflation may not be a bad thing. Balance sheet risks appear lower than for UK life, but we note DLG and RSA have UK infrastructure and property exposures. Saga looks more insulated with a low risk balance sheet.

BE11:38am

So, they like : Allianz, Prudential, Saga, Swiss Life, NN Group, Tryg and Baloise.

Swill of the People How long until some of the neo-banks (Monzo, Revolut) IPO and need to start making money to justify their obscene valuations?
11:39 am
undefined
GBKrona brill, thanks @BE
BE11:39am

@Flaneur, agreed for once. There's a longer version of the letter here: https://medium.com...d-div-2d2c6aa736c5

#REF! My computer is being rebuilt today and is now displaying text horribly. I suffer to read ML...
wayneJ The issue of insurance companies trading in the EU via subsidiaries, is surely the same as for banks, ie the subs have to be separately financed and ringfenced so is very capital inefficient? Or am I missing something?
Shinshin @Flaneur You'll note that none of the official responses address the substance of the letter, nor commit to any action
#REF! I'm looking forward to the FT moving and ML having more technical issues due to the move.....
Tom Dalgleish @Patience, yes, between standalone vets, vets in retail shops and standalone retail it's not clear where the problems are.
Excel Developer I found the parliamentary war-gaming numbers I was talking about yesterday. https://twitter.com/pswidlicki/status/1051801915259060224
Tom Dalgleish You'd be surprised how themes play out like that but we lack a listed cake shop to test it further
#REF! @Tom Cakebox listed this year. Egg free cakes. Surprisingly tasty
Pharma @Flaneur, Summers was beaten to his epiphany by The Onionhttps://www.theonion.com/midwest-discovered-between-east-and-west-coasts-1819567923
BE11:42am

And it's very fair criticism. We're a homogeneous office.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Which reminded me of this great column the other week by Matt Levine about Amazon's robo HR department: https://www.bloomb...arn-by-watching-us

Tom Dalgleish @Ref, gruel could go down well here
BE11:44am

If you build a machine-learning robot and ask it “who are the best employees” and it goes out and examines the world and comes back and says “men, it’s men, men are the best,” then that tells you something surprising and complicated about either the world or your robot. But if you build a machine-learning robot and ask it “who are the candidates we like to hire” and it goes out and examines your hiring decisions and comes back and says “men, it’s men, you hire men,” then that tells you something quite straightforward about your hiring decisions.

undefined
Mark Shapland any thoughts on Pearson tomorrow?
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Okay, so we've a network slowdown and I'm struggling to summon the energy to keep fighting it. Let's do some supermarkets as a means to get us through to midday.

Roidster @BE thanks for your comments on RPC
BE11:46am

Kantar UK grocery sales up 3.2% for 12 weeks to October 7

TB Interesting article from FT on Luxury pushing share prices of Tod's and Ferragamo higher today although Prada ended down
BE11:46am

Aldi leading.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

15.1% growth. Wm Morrison was 2.4%, Tesco 0.9%, Sainsbury 0.6%

urgeview Any chance of some MERL coverage ?
WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 247.30, down 0.3 (-0.12%), High: 250.15, Low: 246.75, Volume: 2.56m
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 206.80, down 9.2 (-4.26%), High: 216.00, Low: 205.90, Volume: 11.72m
11:47 am
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 301.60, down 3.8 (-1.24%), High: 307.50, Low: 300.20, Volume: 2.65m
BE11:47am

Food inflation flat at 2%

BE11:47am

Here's Barclays.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Of the big four, we think that:

· ASDA might be the most satisfied with its showing in this set of data because (on a 12 week basis) it is the fastest growing and the only one to expand its market share.

§ Tesco and Sainsbury might be the least satisfied with their showing in this set of data because they have both seen sales decline (on a 4 week basis). Both have seen their market share losses increase sequentially, Tesco more than Sainsbury.

§ Morrison continued to see sales grow, but it saw a loss in market share for the first time since June.

· Our overall conclusion would be that the discounters will take more satisfaction from these figures than the “conventional” retailers. On a combined basis, their 12-week growth of 12.9% is the fastest we have seen since February.

mbt Thanks BE :)
Roidster @BE - must admit my local Tesco - shabby and high prices - ASDA far ahead - will not shop at tescos unless have to....and Their wine prices....extortionate - Hic!;)
BE11:49am

And JP Morgan.

Excel Developer New Aldi in my town, I've don;t like their baked beans, will stick with Lidl.
BE11:50am

Actually, not JP Morgan. It wasn't worth opening. Here's Goldman.

Roidster LOL...we have a new Lidl just about to open up near us....right by my sons school - no brainer - ill be going there !
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Tesco: continues to disappoint, driven by food and drink sales -1.7% (in stark contrast to Asda +3.1%). While this may be driven by range disruption around the new Everyday at Tesco range as we have noted, Tesco’s share price performance is closely correlated to market share gains and the trend is getting worse, not better.

Tom Dalgleish I reiterate my statement from yesterday that if shoplifting was eradicated Amazon would be gone tomorrow and retail would bounce back
BE11:51am

Discounters: consistent with the prior period, discounters continued to see their share gains accelerate, with Lidl seeing a re-acceleration in the period. This will add further weight to the argument that the slowdown in early 2018 was driven by the timing of new store openings. As we noted last month, it could also be an indicator of trading down in the space, with M&S (-3.2%) and Sainsbury (-0.7%) the worst performing formats in the period. Though an improvement on last month’s -3.1%, Waitrose’s sales growth remained low at +0.7%.

ElonTheMask Very interesting name in insurance UNUM group, been in talks in the past with SunLife and MetLife according to WSJ, seems that last months talks have revived, maybe time for a deal. Peers deal P/E points to an over $ 50 dollars valuation in a takeover scenario
BE11:52am

Ocado, btw, is a Merrill upgrade.

11:52 am
Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 825.00, up 35.2 (+4.46%), High: 834.00, Low: 811.20, Volume: 724.29k
Roidster @excel - re Ali baked beans - your correct - they taste to "synthetically" sweet in my opinion - i get branston beans from Asda - Yummy! (faarrrt!)
Maverick CMA to consider impact of Lidl and Aldi in Sainsburys Asda merger investigation
Roidster Aldi
BE11:52am

Buy from underperform. Valuation mostly.

BE11:52am

With share price down by c.25% over the past four months, we regard Ocado stock as back to buying territory. The current share price is not reflecting the value of Ocado's unique online grocery solution, in our view. Double upgrade to Buy with our price objective unchanged at £10.20.

Gillibrand How are the discount supermarkets doing?
Patience @Roidster - my Tesco Local (or whatever) has drinkable Malbec at £7, and sometimes half-decent Chianti or Rioja twixt £8 and £10.

undefined

wayneJ Isn't the point about Legoland that the next movie is next yr?

BE11:58am

Here's Numis.

11:58 am

For Legoland lfl growth of -0.3% is a deterioration on 0.9% in 1H and compares to our +0.9% forecast. The market was aware of marketing issues in H1 but Legoland has also suffered from the lack of product investment this year, which will change in 2019 when the Lego Movie 2 is released.

BE11:58am

Wasn't Lego Batman the second Lego movie?

Roidster @BE...any views on Convatec CTEC?

Roidster seems a bit oversone to me (on the fall that is)

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Anyway, back to Numis.

BE12:00pm

FY19 margin & outlook: guidance for stable margins in the year is unchanged. For FY19 there is a cautious comment around rising wage pressures and tighter labour markets.

wayneJ Also Merlin has increasing US / global exposure which will ultimately make it a great GBP hedge.
BE12:00pm

While the group's productivity agenda is expected to provide significant mitigation the full benefits are not expected until beyond 2019. This may lead to trimming of the consensus range {top of £547m is 3% ahead of mean} but our assumptions of 3.4% lfl growth and margins -20bp remain realistic. Given that 1ppt on lfl has a 5% impact on EPS, the trend in London is more relevant in our view.

Blank canvas thanks for everything today. :)
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

MERL has outperformed the FTAS by 9% in 2018 to date but is -8% over the last 3m as a profit warning from Parques Reunidos weighed on sentiment. It is also 20% below the peak from Oct'17. The stock trades on FY19 EV/EBITDA of 9.6x and offers 23% upside to our DCF-based price target.

BE12:01pm

That price target being 454p.

wayneJ IF Parques warned but Merlin did not does that not show Merlin is a better quality co. and ought to go up? Confused of Tunbridge Wells.
BE12:01pm

And MOST.

urgeview Cheers BE
12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

We forecast revenues of £1.66bn in FY18 (+4.0%), EBITDA of £490m (+3.5%), PBT of £276m (+2.0%) and EPS of 20.8p (+1.6%), slightly ahead of consensus at £1.67bn, £486m, £268m and 20.3p, respectively. Merlin shares trade on 9.6x EV/EBITDA and 16.1x P/E for 2019e, supported by strong brands, an attractive industry, a diversified portfolio, improved digital strategy, new IP to be signed and a long runway of global roll-out potential. We rate the shares Overweight.

undefined
wayneJ The lodging (ie hotel) aspect is also interesting - if you have young kids is a welcome change from the Disney venues....
wayneJ (Bit of pyschobabble in the Wiki summary of The Lego Batman Movie: 'During his latest mission to stop Joker from destroying the city, he hurts his arch-rival's feelings by telling him he is not as important in his life as he thinks he is, leading Joker to seek the ultimate revenge on him. ')
BE12:03pm

Speaking of MOST, Q3 numbers just crossed. Looks bang in line.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

But we're through midday so I'm making the executive decision not to care.

Soundbuy Cheers all...........
GBKrona thanks @BE, ROTR
BE12:05pm

Apologies for the slow session today. There were mitigating circumstances. Ta for the comments, and back tomorrow.

BE12:05pm

Afternoon all.

wayneJ @BE - what would Bruce Wayne say - not caring has consequences....
wayneJ (See above)
